comments.commentBody: Yes, but I can't rest until I hear what Michele Bachmann tells me what God thinks about all of this.

The "Secession" comment is repetitively being so completely overplayed.
States are subordinate to the Federal Gvt....the Federal Government is the "authority figure" for the purpose of using an analogy.
Find even a single employee in any business of any size, that hasn't grown tired of having to follow the dictates of the "authority figure" and made some utterance similar to "I'm so sick of having to do these things i don't agree with, I'm thinking about just quitting....just walk out the door to be able to make my own decisions."
I would venture that it is not an overestimation to say tens of millions of people....or more... have expressed their present status frustrations in exactly the same as Perry's Secession comment.

My family of 4's flight was cancelled on Saturday morning. After multiple hour-plus phone calls we scored a direct flight EWR > SFO on Monday. However, the airline failed to give us E-tickets. We had to wait on a ticketing line for 45 minutes while the same two customers were trying to sort out their travel plans (i.e. they didn't have reservations or tickets, etc).

At my second protest that we (and the rest of the line) would miss our flight an employee from the neighboring line said that he couldn't help us because he wasn't a manager. I asked him to call his manager and his co-worker managing our line said that she would call the police on me (in front of my wife and daughters age 4 and 2).

This problem is the airlines' making. They know they will have problems like this many times per year (snow storms, wind storms, etc). They need to fly extra staff (think experts) into the area to handle the logistics of these mass cancellations / rebookings. Understand that efficiency during these situations makes everyone's experience more positive. Sadly, they don't seem to care. If we had missed our flight they would have filled it with a standby and wouldn't have reimbursed us for the incompetence that was proudly on display.

Bravo airlines... my next vacation might be by car.

I'm surprised that the airlines waited so long to start canceling flights.

Two years ago when we had one of the two huge snow storms in the Northeast I was flying from Atlanta to Philadelphia. I was flying out Friday afternoon and the snow was scheduled to start Friday late evening and not begin to come down hard until Saturday early morning. On Thursday night Delta canceled all the Friday flights taking off at 4pm and later to Philly. I thought they were overreacting, but at least they put my on an earlier flight. And this is probably the only time Delta has been so accommodating.

Here's a sample from Alan Krueger:

"From an American perspective it would, perhaps, seem natural to lower the levels of the social safety nets and in this way make the unemployed persons seek, find and accept new job offers more rapidly."

http://people.su.se/~calmf/Ekonomisk%20politik/IntermacroEc_ht08/RapArt/...

which puts hinm in lockstep with team Obama in wanting to CUT SOCIAL SECURITY.

Obama is a fraud.

De-elect the president.
So if "like minded" Texans decided to re-establish slavery, it would be their state's right?
How did the Republican Party get to be so mean-spirited?

Since no doubt something like this will happen again, how about trying this:  Watch the news to get information you need, then TURN OFF THE TV/COMPUTER/RADIO/WHATEVER, prepare as necessary, and then do the things you need or want to do. Half the problem seems to be that people stay glued to the media and get scared out of their wits by subjecting themselves to the constant updates. The media really do need to report on dangerous weather 24/7. It's one of the things they're actually useful for, even if they go overboard sometimes. But people don't need to live in a bubble of disaster reporting for hours or days on end. Heck, if my life is going to end, I sure don't want to spend my last few hours fretting over things I can't possibly affect!

"A. J. Burnett ... has been bad against everyone recently. His E.R.A. in his last five starts is 11.91, and he faces one of the best offensive teams in baseball in its small ballpark."

The stupidity of continuing to keep Burnett in the rotation despite his record - which gets worse with each outing - is mind numbing, especially against the first place team, the Yankees' biggest rivals. What can they be thinking? How many games are they willing to knowingly toss away before they accept the reality - that Burnett is no longer a major league pitcher? And for cryin' out loud, don't put him in bullpen. They've got enough problems there already. Just bench him. It's the only move that makes any sense.

Tom Alamo makes a good point.  The Red Sox could charge more for their tickets.  As it is, though, their average ticket price is something like 2nd highest in the majors ($52-$53 per ticket), so they're not exactly giving tix away.  The aftermarket sellers like Ace (which has an "official" relationship with the Sox) and StubHub (which rebates some proceeds to MLB) buy or broker thousands and thousands of tix and sell them for more than face, on average.  Result:  Red Sox always sell out, which is great marketing buzz, but tickets are usually available in the aftermarket (even 2 or 3 thousand a game).  Oddly, everyone benefits.  That's why it works!

Why did Noesi get sent down? It should have been AJ. Let him join Igawa and his 85 mph flatball in Trenton. Although the upcoming games with Boston really don't mean anything, there's the little matter of pride. CC needs to step up tomorrow and Burnett needs to be scrapped. Why not give Noesi a shot? As @Davey points out, Burnett's a sure way to lose a game and smoke the bullpen. Last things we need. What's Joe thinking?

I am a Ravens fan.  This article caught our strengths and weaknesses well.  As much as it annoys me.....probably a good prediction to.  One thing though, we got younger this year.  If we can't take the Steelers this year, and we might, watch out next year.

It is wrong to compare this one to Katrina in that many of the flooded areas were among the most beautiful vacation locations in the northeast , ie adirondacks , catskills, the jersey shore. I remember going to the catskills liberty, monticello, as a child and we never experienced flooding in the summers. Hurricanes now are reaching the northeast unheard of , and they carry over land the tropical rain from the ocean. Some think we need to build more dams and for hydroelectric power but when dams break they cause even more catastrophic floods. Thankfully the walls of water didnt tear down the walls of any nuclear facilties.
The rush of water in non flood prone areas, Bulls head, SI, upstate(greensville) and vermont makes me think that perhaps more reservoirs, drainage facilities(sewers), widening of river embankments, are needed. Developers must stop building in low lying areas and marshes and the buying public is duped. When was the last time we saw the army corps of engineers do work in NY state?

Here in Keene Valley and especially Keene there is utter destruction.; roads gone, bridges gone, firehouse
(in Keene) gone, businesses gone. This is the "Home of the High Peaks"--for many they now remain inaccessible.

I sense a great deal of anger in the comments from my fellow Times Readers.  I wonder where that anger comes from and I think its from a general feeling of unfairness that has overtaken our lives.  This unfairness is could come from many things but I think its mostly from feeling that our life is not as good as it could be because of things outside of our control.  That there are things or people or ways that are taking away from what we think should be ours.  These things could be rules, policies, thoughts, ideas, beliefs and doctrines that did not exist before but now are in place to press down upon us.  We feel like any symbol of those things like powerful bankers, politicians, financial and societal elites can become the target of this righteous anger because they have unbalanced the scales in their favor. People only live for a finite amount of time, and its during that time, that they can choose to be positive (giving back to society) or negative (take from society).  It seems for the last 30 years, we have regressed as a nation that teaches our future generations to take more than to give back.  No one ever talks about the peace corp or becoming teachers and public servants.  We have been trained to push the next generation to do better than us, to get better educations, to strive to be successful, to be rich, beautiful, popular, winners in life, not losers.  In that context, we have succeeded more than we know.  Our kids are now climbing that ladder of success and stepping over anyone in their way to drive the biggest car, own the biggest house, wear the best clothes, have the best vacations, buy the best of everything they can to show they have arrived.  Our current leaders are the result of those lessons, lessons not about loving your fellow man, caring for the downtrodden, or giving to the less fortunate.  Instead, we are driven to be winners and in this society, winners have it all and don't care for anyone but themselves.

I am glad to see what's happening in northern New York, Vermont, Connecticut and New Hampshire is finally getting some coverage. I watched in amazement on Sunday morning as Anderson Cooper seemed put out that he couldn't just roll out of bed on Manhattan's west side and cover a natural disaster. What?, the Empire State Building didn't collapse? City Hall is not under water? Too bad. But upstate New York and New England are being devastated. Some towns are disappearing in a 500 year flood. Not to mention New Jersey, Pennsylvania and all the other states struck by Irene.

Did the media really want another Katrina? 40 dead, tens of billions in damage and 5 million without power isn't good enough? I praise Bloomberg, Christie and all the public officials who forced evacuations. They may have saved hundreds of lives.

For the media, get out there and cover what IS happening and stop hoping it comes right to your doorstep along with the New York Times.

As a trained aircraft engineer I find the television program "Air Crash Investigations" interesting.  One thing that becomes apparent from this program is that Russia does not have a monopoly on airline disasters, in fact American aircraft seem to feature most often.  That still doesn't mean that I am going to fly in a Russian airliner and I am even less likely to fly in a Chinese made or owned one either.

Al from NYC: "from the most modern country in the world"

Heh heh... visit Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland or any of the Scandinavian countries some day. You will notice that the infrastructure here in the US is a joke. Joke from the sixties.

What an unbelievable sense of smugness displayed by Americans here! I hope it comes in handy when the aging Boeings transporting you over USA begin experiencing metal fatigue in the air, as already happened to Southwest earlier this year.

We need ecologically sound, efficient, and less costly alternatives to air travel, even if government has to subsidize them at first, as it did early air travel. Flying distances less than 500 miles does not make much sense, as the airline themselves show as they reduce such service.
I'm happy to have not been on a plane in 7 years. The trouble and aggravation,and total lack of customer service,make flying, something to avoid.
Many people tell me they have been assisted by my "airline survival guide" for emergencies: http://meteorologicalmusings.blogspot.com/2011/01/airline-crisis-surviva...
Gee, I think that I almost agree with Ron in post 25. Move the dicator in with Mr. Bush.

The only people I pity--sincerely--in this article are the woman who gave birth without adequate medical aid, and the infant born in those circumstances. I have no idea what the woman may or may not have done in other ways in the Khaddafi tribe, of course, but in that moment she and her baby were innocent and in hostile conditions. Even in war and in a dictatorship, people must be treated humanely, and anyone who wishes it to be otherwise is as shameful as those who harm others.

However, I am very nervous about what will happen in Libya and in the other parts of the Arab world (and around the world, in fact) which are going through violent transitions. Who will take over? Will they be compassionate and able leaders, or just more bloodthirsty megalomaniacs?

The next leader who I would want to be brought down from leadership (and the destruction he has wreaked on his country) is the president of Zimbabwe. He has destroyed his country and the people of his country systematically and with impunity. This is one person who deserves swift exile and stripping of all his (and his regime's) resources and powers.
